docs.lead_paragraph: In Fort Greene, Brooklyn, the residents of a housing project had had enough of the pockmarked patchwork of drug corners and shuttered stores, so they formed a neighborhood group, worked with housing police and got Government money to start a nightly patrol. In a neighborhood in Ozone Park, Queens, people who were distressed when the city slashed its budget for youth programs last year turned to their neighborhood association, which lobbied for a $5,000 city grant and rounded up volunteers to start after-school tutoring and art classes.

headline.main: NEIGHBORHOOD MUSCLE -- A special report.;In Era of Shrinking Budgets, Community Groups Blossom
